Hello, I'm Amy!

I am a first year student and NSF GRPF fellow at the University of Washington in the Department of Human-Centered Design and Engineering, where I am advised by Dr. Emily Tseng.

My work explores humanistic approaches to digital safety with a focus on community-centered models of resilience and care for harm both facilitated  and enacted  by technology. I am often asking "what is safety?" and "who gets to be safe?" —thinking about what that means for how we design and govern technology (and in response to it). My research is grounded in critical social studies, but is primarily empirical, mixed-method, and participatory. Through it, I seek to contribute both practical artifacts (protocols, design, data) and conceptual frameworks of analysis.

Previously, I was at Brown University where I worked with the Brown HCI Lab (now Socio-HCI @ Brown) and the Human Trafficking Research Cluster.

Get in touch at amywxiao@uw.edu (institutional) or amyw.xiao@gmail.com (personal). You can also connect with me on LinkedIn!

A headshot of me, an Asian person with bangs and teal dip-dyed hair. Super stylish of course.

What am I working on?

In my research, I am often thinking about il/legibility in socio-technical systems and how that impacts the safety and wellbeing afforded to marginalized communities. This has led me to work on projects like:

  • Mapping the intersection of help-seeking and sensemaking dynamics through the collaborative identification (or mis-identification) of scams targeting immigrants.
  • Visualizing immigrant workers experience of anti-trafficking surveillance technology through the juxtaposition of oral histories and historical municipal data.
  • Designing accessible communication technology with respect to frameworks of neurodiversity and accessibility.
  • Exploring how AI has impacted advice-seeking behaviors on interpersonal relationships and how users conceptulize the social roles, risks, and rewards of AI chatbots.

In the past, I have published or presented my projects at venues like CHI, CSCW, AIES, and AAAS. Translational work has also been an important part of my scholarship, adapting my research to public-facing settings like legislatures, art galleries, and community workshops!
